Software System: CRIME & CRIMINAL TRACKING NETWORK AND SYSTEMS (CCTNS)
Environment Object: MINISTRY OF HOME AFFAIRS GOVERNMENT OF INDIA
the expected range of technical contexts of use
System Requirements: introduces operational efficiencies by automating most of the tasks that take place after initial entries are made during Registration
Interfacing with the courts during the prosecution of cases
respond to citizens with very little turnaround time
cut short the drudgery of large amounts of paperwork
all the possible actions and scenarios
provide an interface for the user to log any defects or enhancement requests
An audit trail is a record of actions taken
capable of automatically capturing and storing information
capable of automatically capturing and storing information about the date and time of the event
for the life of the case
The CCTNS system must be able to export audit trails for specified cases (without affecting the audit trail stored by The CCTNS system)
allow the user to limit access to cases to specified users or user groups
The CCTNS system must allow a user to be a member of more than one group
must not include such cases in any count of search results
make unauthorised attempts to access cases
The CCTNS system must employ a single set of user interface rules, or a small number of sets to provide a familiar and common look and feel for the application
The CCTNS system must be able to display several entity (cases, suspects) simultaneously.
must be made customizable or user-configurable
The CCTNS system user interface must be suitable for users with special needs; that is, compatible with specialist software that may be used and with appropriate interface guidelines
must provide End User and Administrator functions which are easy to use and intuitive throughout
allow persistent defaults for data entry
values derived from context, e.g.date, file reference, user identifier
Frequently-executed System transactions must be designed so that they can be completed with a small number of interactions
Customisation should include, but need not be limited to the following changes: menu contents; layout of screens; use of function keys; on-screen colours, fonts and font sizes;
All non-text media objects, such as graphical images or video, should be provided with alternative equivalent textual descriptions and/or with equivalent text-based functionality

Each presentation segment (page or window) should provide the user with a clear and sufficient indication of where he or she is in the navigation structure and of the current segment position with respect to the overall structure
navigating to a specific unit of content
Horizontal scrolling should be avoided wherever possible.
User interfaces should be designed to allow activation of controls by a variety of input devices
The ability to choose between different input devices for activating controls such as links, fields and buttons
User interfaces should be designed to be as robust as possible in the face of changing technology
important for user navigation and exploration

When designing user interfaces for use by diverse groups, input and output of information elements such as currency, units of measurement, temperatures, date and time, phone numbers, address or postal codes should be designed so that they are usable.
Text should be able to be resized by the user
The quality of textual content with respect to spelling and grammar should be sufficient so as not to impede readability.

The reading and understanding of the textual content on the screen should be supported by suitable means, including the use of short sentences, the division of the text into shorter chunks or the presentation of content items in the form of bullet points.
Within-page links should be clearly distinguishable from other links that lead to a different page
The target or purpose of a link should be directly indicated by its label

avoiding generic labels such as “go” or “click here” except where the purpose of the link is clear from its context on the page or the labels have commonly understood semantics in the particular application domain
Links that open new browser windows or pop-up windows should be clearly marked
should be clearly distinguishable from controls activating some action
a printer-friendly version of the document
The length of a page should be selected so as to support the primary purpose and use of the page
Color should never be the only means of coding
how frames relate to one another
an alternative way of presenting relevant information
it should be possible for the user to read and understand the page
the user should be provided with an equivalent alternative text-only page
Page titles should be placed in a consistent location on the different pages
Practical guidelines for presenting information to the user
Each page should contain a link leading to the home page of the application or to a landmark page that is easy to recognize for the user.
A separate navigation overview such as a site map should be provided for application showing the structure of the site in an overview form
Consistency between navigation components and content
customizing the user interface to their personal needs
individualization designing content and navigation differently
retrieve and display within 5-8 seconds the case which has been accessed within the previous 2 months
retrieve and display within 20 seconds the case which has not been accessed within the previous 2 months
regardless of storage capacity or number of cases in the CCTNS system
allow for cases where cases used infrequently are stored
advancement in open standards and web technologies
The deployment of the application will be at state level and will be configured and customized as per the state specific extensions
should be designed with the following broad guidelines
designed in manner that operational data is not lost in case of any failure of equipment or communication network
work even in an offline mode with the critical functionality
should be implemented using Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) and have a modular design
should be developed for a centralized deployment and maintenance
to have a n-tier architecture with the presentation logic separated from the business logic that is again separated from the data-access logic
adopt standardized formats and common metadata elements
support selective encryption of the stored data
high standards of security and access control
fetch only the fields that need to be displayed
A hierarchical cache should be configured and used for caching of results of most frequently used searches
Alert medical staff in case of emergencies
Shared Phenomena: the results view by criminal/accused or by cases
all the actions (create/read/update/delete) that are taken upon the critical entity
the displayed columns in the table
useful content or feedback about the application state
actions the user can take to resolve the error
the behaviour of all users or a user group
validating the incoming data or user request
